In the heterogeneous catalyst domain, there has been an incessant demand in recent decades with a focus on introducing environmentally friendly and sustainable materials. Because of their distinct structural properties, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are emerging as a new class of active materials for organic reactions; sophisticated hybrid catalytic materials can now be fabricated with improved recyclability, separability, and activity for specific organic processes by integrating MOFs with metallic nanoparticles. Herein, we deliberate on several MOF-based nanostructured catalysts that facilitate selected organic transformations. Examples comprise, among others, the Baeyer-Villiger oxidation, cyanation of aldehydes, cycloalkane oxidation, epoxidation of cyclohexenes, esterification, Heck reaction, tandem reactions, Sonogashira and Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reactions, which exploit the catalysts' reactivity, reusability, and interactions with the inherent properties of the deployed MOF-based nanostructured catalysts. The benefits, shortcomings, reusability, and efficiency aspects of the introduced catalysts are reviewed. A succinct conclusion is offered, along with a commentary on the major hurdles encountered today and prospective future research needs related to the MOF-based catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Metal-organic frameworks Organic reaction Catalysis Nanocatalyst Green process, Cross-coupling reaction Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The term "metal-organic framework" (MOF) refers to a group of porous materials that feature metal nodes connected by organic linkers [1–7]. Because of their modular design, they are highly accessible synthetically and can be finely tuned in terms of both structural and chemical properties [8–10]. Porosity, particle morphology, and stability are just a few examples of MOFs’ properties that can be specifically tailored through inventive synthetic design for eventual deployment in water remediation, electronics, biomolecule encapsulation, catalysis, gas storage and separation, and other fields [11–16]. As a result of their porous networks and substantial surface areas, MOFs are able to quickly transfer electrons and ions from active metal sites. When designed and manufactured under controlled conditions; therefore, MOF-based materials can be used to fabricate highly active electrocatalysts [17–20]. Due to the increased interest in creating new environmentally friendly and sustainable chemical processes in response to rising energy needs and pollution abatement, catalysis has become one of the fastest growing fields in chemistry [21–23]; two distinct categories being homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts [24–28]. When it comes to chemical reactions, homogeneous catalysts are more selective. Heterogeneous catalysts, on the other hand, are employed for large-scale processes, such as hydrocarbon cracking and 3-way catalytic conversions in the automotive industry. Heterogeneous catalysis is preferable from a practical standpoint because it allows the catalyst to be recycled and the product to be easily separated from the catalyst [29–34]. Nevertheless, it is not always possible to obtain the same levels of selectivity and activity in heterogeneous systems compared to their homogeneous counterparts. The production of assorted nanostructured materials to support different homogeneous catalysts has advanced significantly in recent years, thus enabling practical solutions. However, it is still difficult to achieve cost-effective and ecologically safe protocols to specify heterogeneous catalysts with profitable industrial benefits [35–37]. In this regard, MOFs as porous and recyclable materials have demonstrated exceptional adaptability and offered consistent quality to the supported heterogeneous catalysts, allowing for extremely effective and environmentally friendly chemical reactions [38–40]. The chemical industries rely heavily on catalytic organic transformations since they are essential to the completion of many operations [41–43]. A cursory review of literature reveals that a variety of MOF-based catalysts have been introduced for various organic transformations culminating in greener processes. While there are many review articles available on the development and applications of MOFs, a review on MOF-based catalysts for organic reactions is still lacking [44–47]. Consequently, various organic transformations catalyzed by MOF-based nanostructured catalysts constitute the primary emphasis of this review paper with a focus on widely deployed organic reactions. The concepts and rationale behind how these catalysts might be altered to work effectively and be applied in various organic transformations are expounded using selected examples. They comprise, among others, the amidation of aldehydes and amines, arylation of inactivated arenes, Baeyer-Villiger oxidation, cyanation of aldehydes, cycloalkane oxidation, deacetalization-Knoevenagel condensation reactions, desulfurization of thiophene-type sulfur compounds, epoxidation of cyclohexene, esterification reaction, Heck reaction, hydrogenation of alkynes, hydrogenation of nitroaromatics, isomerization reactions of methylcyclopentane, multicomponent reactions, tandem reactions, oxidation of alcohols, oxidation of sulfides, oxidative dehydrogenative homo-coupling of amines to imines, cross-coupling of amines with alcohols to amides, Si-H insertion, Sonogashira and Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reactions. The highlights include their execution under more environmentally friendly circumstances, the logic behind the enhanced activity, rendering them recyclable via functionalization, appropriate control over the composition, and the inherent properties of the newly introduced MOF-based nanostructured catalysts. 2 Amidation of aldehydes and amines Amide-bond formation is an important organic process in the synthesis of natural products, polymers, and pharmaceuticals such as anticancer drugs, peptides, nylon, etc. [48,49]. Amidation of aldehydes and amines can be accomplished with the deployment of effective and recyclable MOF-based catalysts. As shown in Fig. 1 , Jamalifard et al. [50] enhanced the oxidative amidation of aldehydes (1) with a primary amine (2) for synthesizing secondary amides (3) by combining an easily accessible and inexpensive Cu-MOF, as a recyclable catalyst with tertbutyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) and N-chlorosuccinimide (NCS) as oxidants. After optimization of the model reaction, a variety of amines and aromatic aldehydes were reacted under the ideal conditions to decipher the substrate scope of this reaction (Table 1 ); attempts invariably resulted in high yields of secondary amides. High to excellent yields of secondary amides were obtained from aldehydes containing either electron-withdrawing or electron-donating substituents, demonstrating that the reaction is insensitive to electronic interactions. Fig. 2 depicts a potential mechanism for this reaction. TBHP was converted into a tert‑butylperoxy radical as a result of TBHP oxidation by Cu(II), which also resulted in Cu(II) reduction to Cu(I). Benzaldehyde was converted into a benzoyl radical after being attacked by the tert‑butylperoxy radical, which abstracted a hydrogen from the aldehyde. As a result of the redox reaction, the N-chloramine, as the product of the reaction between NCS and benzylamine, was converted into an amino radical. The final step involved the coupling of benzoyl radical with the amino radical to produce the amide compounds. Overall, the study's findings suggest that this new low-cost amide synthesis reaction offers viable alternatives for the generation of amides under mild reaction conditions. 3 Arylation of arenes There has been an increase in the use of direct arylation of aromatic CH bonds as a replacement for conventional cross-couplings [51,52]. The cross-coupling of aryl halides with inactivated arenes has been proposed by Liu et al. [53] as a reusable and highly selective MOF-based catalyst with the assistance of transition metals wherein the reaction is facilitated by the organic linkers. In this study, the MOF-253, (Al(OH)(bpydc)), was created from 2,2′-bipyridine-5,5′-dicarboxylate (bpydc) and Al. The 2,2′-bipyridine (bpy) moieties in the MOF structure were not coupled with metal ions, thus enabling the organic compounds to serve as catalytic centers. Initial optimization focused on the cross-coupling of benzene and 4-iodoanisole with assorted bases utilized in the reactions and MOF-253. According to Table 2 , only one examined base, KOt-Bu, produced the favorable product (3a) in 50% of yield (entry 1), while all others were unproductive. Extending the reaction period, it was possible to convert 1a completely and with >99% selectivity to 3a (entry 3). It is worth mentioning that the reaction might still occur, though less efficiently, at lower benzene loadings. Due to the absence of exposed Al ions in the MOF, it is unable to attribute the special reactivity of MOF-253 to its metal ions as the yield and conversion were unaffected by the addition of Al ions to the process (entries 4 and 6). These findings show that integrating bpydc ligands within a MOF structure dramatically increased their catalytic efficiency in the cross-couplings. Due to charge exchanges between nearby metals and ligands, it is believed that the electron configuration of the constituent ligands differs significantly from that of an individual molecule scattered in solution. They further explored two other MOFs, ZIF-67 (Co(MeIM)2) and ZIF-8 (Zn(MeIM)2), to lend support to this finding. Both of these MOFs have a bidentate chelating nitrogen core, similar to the bpydc, and comprised of 2-methylimidazole (MeIM); ZIF-67 and ZIF-8 may both work as effective catalysts to enhance this direct arylation, even though MeIM did not provide the requisite coupling products (entries 7–9). The results indicate that building the ligand within a MOF material would be a promising technique to improve the performance of a compound in the direct arylation. 4 Baeyer-Villiger oxidation The Baeyer-Villiger oxidation reaction converts ketones into lactones or esters, which are useful intermediates in several chemical industries [54,55]. In order to catalyze the Baeyer-Villiger oxidation of cyclohexanone, Alavijeh et al. [56] employed MOFs comprising copper and tin metal salts (MIL-101(Cr)). Initially, varying concentrations of tin chloride and copper nitrate were dissolved in ethanol and then were added to the pre-activated MIL-101(Cr) to generate CuII-SnIV@MIL-101(Cr) with various metal percentages. After 24 h of stirring, the resultant mixture was heated to 50 °C until the solvent was completely evaporated (Fig. 3 ). Catalysts containing varying amounts of tin and copper ions were synthesized and given the designations CuII-SnIV@ MIL-101(Cr)/A, B, C, D, E, and F, corresponding to Cu-Sn metal content (%) of 0.37–0.79, 0.59–1.18, 0.78–1.57, 0.78–4.74, 2.36–1.54, and 2.36–4.71. This study established that the losses in cavity size and surface area of the catalysts with higher metal species loadings did not significantly contribute to the decline in catalytic performance. The results demonstrated that the oxidative strength of the catalyst increased with enhanced metal content, and a portion of the benzaldehyde was oxidized to benzoic acid before entering the principal reaction pathway and generating ԑ-caprolactone, which was reduced by lowering the concentration of benzaldehyde. But over the intermolecular dehydration phase, a lot of benzoic acid was generated in the reaction medium which was then transformed to benzoic anhydride. This experiment examined the impact of varying the time at which the cyclohexanone oxidation reaction was carried out. Fig. 4 aI shows that the yield of the product increased from 34% to 100% as the reaction time was prolonged from 1 to 5 h, which then stayed stable as the reaction time rose further. Heterogeneity of this catalyst was verified by a hot filtering test (Fig. 4aII). The catalyst's effectiveness did not significantly decrease after being recycled five times (Fig. 4b). The removal of catalyst from the reaction media ceased the catalytic activity, demonstrating the catalyst's heterogeneity and the lack of leaching in the catalytic active sites. In sum, this catalyst can lessen the ecological footprint of the Baeyer-Villiger reaction and cut down on the expenses of producing benzoic acid. 5 Oxidation/Cyanation of alcohols The production of many compounds requires the selective oxidation of alcohols [57]. Co-crystallization of (2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidin-1-yl)oxyl (TEMPO)-substituted enantiopure VO(salen) and tricarboxylate-derived dipyridine ligands (Fig. 5 a and b) allowed Li and coworkers [58] to create a chiral porous MOF decorated with radicals. Evidence suggests that TEMPO can facilitate the selective oxidation of alcohols, and that VO(salen) complexes can catalyze the cyanosilylation of aldehydes with higher efficiency. Accordingly, the conversion of p-bromobenzyl alcohol was selected as an example reaction to evaluate the catalytic activity of the MOF catalyst in asymmetric cyanation of aldehyde/alcohol oxidation. Excellent conversions (91%−98%) were obtained after optimizing the temperature, solvent, and molar ratio of the catalytic components in the oxidation reaction carried out with 2 mol of electron-donating and -withdrawing groups on the benzene ring. Next, they compared the catalytic performance of the prepared catalyst to that of the comparable homogeneous system to assess the role played by the pore architectures of the MOF catalyst. Under identical conditions, VOL2 catalyzed the sequential reactions of o-methoxybenzyl alcohol, p-methoxybenzyl alcohol, benzyl alcohol, and p-bromobenzyl alcohol, producing the corresponding products with conversions of 84%, 82%, 85%, and 78%. It followed that the breadth and general application of the sequential process be investigated. Both electron-withdrawing and -donating benzyl alcohols afforded the expected results, as illustrated in Fig. 6 . These encouraging findings suggest that this study may expand the method for assembling multifunctional MOF catalysts. By utilizing this strategy, it is anticipated that further heterogeneous catalysts with exceptional performance will be found. 6 Cycloalkane oxidation To synthesize a large number of useful compounds, the chemical industry relies exclusively on oxidation reactions [59]. The oxidation of cyclohexane typically produces a combination of the corresponding alcohol and ketone. To examine the impact of a hydrophobic pore structure on the catalyst's durability and product selectivity in a variety of iron-based frameworks, Xiao et al. [60] employed the oxidation of cyclohexane to cyclohexanone and cyclohexanol as a model reaction. Fe2(dobdc) or Fe-MOF-74 is a functionally adaptable MOF that was first explored in the context of O2/N2 separations with outstanding performance in various applications like slow NO release for biomedical uses and paraffin/olefin separations. The coordinatively unsaturated Fe(II) sites that line the hexagonal pores and are both redox-active and Lewis acidic are responsible for the framework's flexibility (Fig. 7 ). In addition, they found that Fe2(dobdc) showed potential as catalysts for hydrocarbon oxidation processes, specifically in the conversion of ethane to acetaldehyde and ethanol in the presence of N2O. The authors synthesized three novel derivatives of Fe2(dotpdc) in which the central ring is substituted with 1,4-di‑tert-butylaryl‒, tetramethyl‒, or tetrafluoro groups to study the impact of local hydrophobic groups on the selectivity and turnover of the catalyst (Fig. 8 ). These three frameworks are referred to as Fe2(dotpdc)R (R = tBu, CH3, and F), where Fe2(dotpdc) stands for the unfunctionalized component. Although these substituents are far from the Fe(II) centers, their position on the core phenylene ring should nevertheless allow them to affect the pore's chemical environment as a whole without interfering with the intended iron-oxo reactivity. Given the potential for ligand hydroxylation, longer-chain alkyl substituents were overlooked. All three frameworks were synthesized under solvothermal conditions, yielding unit cells consistent with the extended M2(dobdc) architecture. The pore sizes and Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface areas decrease as the size of the core substituents rises. The most sterically packed derivative, Fe2(dotpdc tBu ), and Fe2(dotpdc) only vary by ∼10% reductions in surface area and pore size. This study suggests that the impacts of the pore environment and outer coordination sphere may be relevant in the setting of many other MOF-catalyzed transformations, and they deserve further exploration. 7 Deacetalization-Knoevenagel condensation Due to their simplicity, one-pot tandem reactions have recently garnered a lot of interest as they do not require the time-consuming separation and purification of intermediary byproducts; such reactions are both environmentally friendly and economically viable [61–63]. To prepare catalysts for the deacetalization-Knoevenagel condensation, a typical tandem reaction cooperatively catalyzed by acid-base active sites, it is essential that the catalysts have spatial isolation of antagonistic acid-base groups. Zhao et al. [64] deployed an in-situ growing technique to create a variety of chitosan (CS)-coated MOF nanoparticles (NPs) that had high thermal stability, chemical stability, and recyclability (Fig. 9 ). The shell of the CS-coated MOF NPs is composed of CS while the core is composed of the stable material MIL-101(Cr). The CS shell provides Lewis basic sites and Brønsted acidic sites, whereas the MIL-101(Cr) core offers Lewis acidic sites. As a result, the MOF NPs with CS coatings showed remarkable catalytic activity for the one-pot tandem deacetalization-Knoevenagel condensation reaction. According to Table 3 , as CS loading was raised, yield rose steadily; the highest yield being achieved at a MIL-101(Cr)/CS ratio of 2.86:1. (99%; entry 1). The tandem reaction yield dropped off when the CS to MIL-101(Cr) ratio was higher than 2.86, as evidenced by inconsistencies in the powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the MIL-101(Cr)@CS NPs. In addition, when compared to other types of amino-functionalized MOFs and MOFs@CS NPs, the MIL-101(Cr)@CS NPs had the highest catalytic activity. MIL-101(Cr)@CS outperformed other MOFs@CS in terms of catalytic activity because it was synthesized with acetic acid as the solvent, as opposed to methanol, dimethylformamide, ethanol, and so forth; CS compound could be dissolved in acetic acid but was insoluble in organic solvents. It is believed that the utilization of the same acetic acid solvent in the synthesis of MIL-101(Cr)@CS enabled CS to be mixed with MIL-101(Cr) in a more even manner, which resulted in improved catalytic efficiency. In terms of their ability to be recycled, it was uncovered that the MIL-101(Cr)@CS NPs might be recycled and reused with only minimal centrifuging, washing, and drying effort. Using MIL-101(Cr)@CS [MIL-101(Cr)/CS =2.86] as an example, it was evident that after five cycles, the catalyst's morphology did not change, and neither did the conversions nor the yields of the tandem reaction. Overall, the CS-coated MOF NPs synthesis not only expanded the use of MOFs and CS in heterogeneous catalysis, but also offered a practical approach to the development of multipurpose catalysts. 8 Desulfurization of the thiophene-type sulfur compounds The term "desulfurization" refers to a chemical procedure for removing sulfur from a substance [65]. Removing compounds containing sulfur is essential in the chemical industry, especially dealing with fuels. Li et al. [66] scrutinized the catalytic activity of MIL-125 for the oxidative desulfurization reaction and its variation with particle size; MIL-125 with a crystalline size distribution of ∼50–1500 nm was prepared via coordination modulation with trans-cinnamic acid (CA) wherein nanocrystals' porosity could be regulated by CA. Typical type-I isotherm, representing the microporous structure, is displayed by the pristine MIL-125 (Fig. 10 a). Microporosity in the core MIL-125 framework causes all nanocrystal specimens to exhibit type-I isotherms. Furthermore, at a mild pressure, MIL-125-CA-1 displays a type-IV isotherm with minor H4-type hysteresis loops, confirming the presence of mesopores in MIL-125-CA-X, X being the amount of CS in mmol. The mesopores of MIL-125-CA-1 are narrowly centered at 3.9 nm (Fig. 10b). When both MIL-125-CA-5 and MIL-125-CA-3 were modulated with a greater amount of CA, shifts in the hysteresis loops toward higher relative pressures were exhibited. Based on the H3-type hysteresis loops, it is likely that the slit-shaped interparticle pores responsible for the porosity ensue from the aggregation of nanocrystals of a relatively tiny size. Fig. 10b displays the pore size distribution curves determined using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) technique. These specimens showed a hierarchically organized porous structure with a wide range of 2–100 nm pore sizes. Notably, compared to the other specimens, MIL-125-CA-5, which has a mean size of ∼50 nm, exhibits a strikingly higher external surface area. Congruent with the formation of hierarchical porosity, the proportion of micropores progressively decreases as the particle size is reduced. Creating ultra-low-sulfur fuels by deep oxidative desulfurization (ODS) relies on the efficient catalytic oxidation of bulky thiophene derivatives like 4,6-dimethyldibenzothiophene (4,6-DMDBT) and dibenzothiophene (DBT). MIL-125′s catalytic activity was evaluated by oxidative desulfurization of 4,6-DMDBT and DBT to observe the influence of particle size on the catalytic performance. MIL-125-CA-5 displayed the highest catalytic activity among the MIL-125 specimens tested throughout a wide range of particle sizes, as shown in Fig. 11 ; complete elimination by MIL-125-CA-5 was discerned in ∼10 min (Fig. 11a). In contrast, after 10 min, the removal rates of DBT over MIL-125-CA-1, MIL-125-CA-3, and MIL-125 were found to be 80.4%, 91.3%, and 51.1%, respectively. Because of the steric hindrance offered by its two additional methyl groups, 4,6-DMDBT is the most resistant sulfur compound to the ODS reaction. In about 15 min, the MIL-125-CA-5 nanocrystals can eliminate all traces of 4,6-DMDBT (Fig. 11b). In comparison, MIL-25-CA-1, MIL-125-CA-3, and MIL-125 have 81.9%, 93.1%, and 27.7% 4,6-DMDBT elimination rates after 15 min, respectively. The ensuing results show that MIL-125 nanocrystals can have their catalytic performance enhanced for the deep-desulfurization of bulky sulfur compounds by means of their size adjustment. 9 Epoxidation of cyclohexene Epoxides are important intermediates in the organic synthesis of fine compounds, and hence not surprisingly, the epoxidation of olefins has garnered a lot of interest [67]. They are extensively utilized for the preparation of resins, surfactants, paints, organic intermediates, etc. Therefore, many attempts have been made to develop efficient catalysts for epoxide synthesis under mild reaction conditions [68]. To investigate the influence of pore topology and environment on the resulting Mo-supported catalysts, Chen et al. [69] selected a series of MOFs with 8-connected hexanuclear Zr nodes (Zr6 nodes) as supports for Mo(VI) deposition. Fig. 12 shows that the heterogeneous catalyst supports NU-1200, NU-1008, and NU-1000 were chosen because of their hierarchical topologies, which include both mesopores and micropores and allow for the effective diffusion of substrates in these constrained pore settings. Both NU-1008 and NU-1000 have a (4,8)-connected topology and are made up of the tetratopic linkers 1,4-dibromo-2,3,5,6-tetrakis-(4-carboxyphenyl)benzene (H4TCPB-Br2) and 1,3,6,8-tetrakis-(p-benzoic acid)pyrene (H4TBAPy), respectively. Hexagonal mesopores and close triangular micropores are visible in both NU-1008 and NU-1000, which have the same topology (Fig. 12a). The c-pore in NU-1008, however, is smaller than in NU-1000 (Fig. 12b). It has been anticipated that by contrasting these isoreticular MOFs, they could better delineate the effects of subtle variations in c-pore dimensions on the supported catalysts. The 4,4′,4′′-(2,4,6-trimethylbenzene-1,3,5-triyl)tribenzoic acid (TMTB) is used to build NU-1200, and this tri-topic linker results in a (3,8)-connected topology. As the NU-1200′s structure prevents it from having the c-pore that NU-1008 and NU-1000 do, the authors tried to anchor the catalyst just in the mesopore. As a result of the 8-connected nature of the Zr6 nodes in all three MOFs, there are four sites accessible for anchoring active metal ions by virtue of their occupation of the terminal ‒OH/H2O groups on the Zr6 nodes. Since Mo-based catalysts are very effective in epoxidation of olefins, the use of cyclohexene epoxidation as a model reaction has been selected to investigate the impact of the support on the catalyst's performance. Fig. 13 depicts two hypothesized reaction pathways for cyclohexene epoxidation, the direct and radical reaction pathways, with potential products comprising cyclohexanol, cyclohexenone, diol, and epoxide. When H2O2 is heterolytically activated, it can form epoxide, which can then be hydrolyzed to induce ring-opening and afford diol; this pathway is the primary mechanistic route for the epoxidation reaction. Direct H2O2 activation over the deposited Mo sites for the three catalysts yielded epoxide, which was initially the most abundantly observed product. In the beginning, all the catalysts were selective toward epoxide, and as time went on, other compounds began to appear; Mo-NU-1008 revealed a different pattern in diol synthesis than two other catalysts. The drop in epoxide concentration could be due to its re-binding on Mo-NU-1008 and subsequent hydrolysis via reaction with H2O. The active Mo species in Mo-NU-1008, bound in a monodentate form in the hexagonal mesopore, displayed the maximum catalytic performance in the first step of the reaction among all the Mo-supported catalysts tested. This reveals that structural variations in binding motifs of Mo species provide distinct variances in selectivity and catalytic activity. This study demonstrated the significance of MOF supports in controlling the chemical environments of deposited metal species, which affects not only the metal configuration but also the structural development of the metal during catalytic transformations, which in turn affects the selectivity and catalytic activity in heterogeneous catalysis. 10 Esterification of acetic acid Esterification is an important reaction in organic synthesis [70]. Esters are essential for the preparation of bulk and commodity chemicals with well-known applications in polymers, solvents, pharmaceuticals, fragrances, etc. Submicron-sized MOF-76(Yb), denoted as 1a, was produced at ambient temperature by Kiyonaga et al. [71]. Subsequently, the catalyst was heated in a vacuum to create open metal sites (OMS), which function as catalytic sites and are situated at the corners of 1a. An alternative solvothermal synthesis strategy afforded the same hybrid (denoted 1b). Crystal size difference between 1a and 1b was verified by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) wherein particles with columnar shapes and high aspect ratios were found in both compounds (Fig. 14 a and b). Nonetheless, 1a particles were noticeably smaller than 1b. Both compounds also showed no hysteresis in their Type I isotherms for N2 sorption. The BET surface area and pore volume of 1a were 706 m2 g−1 and 0.286 cm3 g−1, respectively, while those values for 1b were 702 m2 g−1 and 0.280 cm3 g−1. To further understand the distinction between 1a and 1b's catalytic characteristics, a model reaction, the isomerization of 1-hexene (Fig. 14c), was carried out. The yields were independent of crystal size, suggesting that all of 1a and 1b's interior pore surfaces were readily accessible to 1-hexene. In addition, the catalytic activity of the catalysts was evaluated under mild conditions by studying the microwave-assisted esterification reaction of acetic acid with methanol. Esterification of acetic acid using methanol was successfully catalyzed by catalysts 1a and 1b; however, in a control test with no MOF-76(Yb) catalyst, the yield was poor. The most striking difference was that the yield for 1a was three times that of 1b. The effect of crystal size on the catalytic performance of MOF-74(Co), MIL-101(Cr), and UiO-66 was also studied. To evaluate the catalytic efficiency of PCP/MOFs 1a and 1b in comparison to those of other systems, the crystal sizes of the catalysts were examined as shown in Fig. 15 ; turnover frequencies (TOFs) for the catalysts being 1a = 2.6 and 1b = 0.8 h−1. It was found that MIL-101(Cr) and UiO-66 crystal sizes had no effect on their catalytic performance in the sub-micron area. These findings demonstrate that the substrate diffusion was unaffected by the particle size and that the size dependency was distinct from that of the metal NPs in MIL-101. Although 1a and 1b were equivalent in both the acidity and structure of the YbIII cations, the considerable differences in the size of the MOF-76(Yb) samples improved the catalytic activity during the esterification reaction. To summarize, a promising strategy for high-performance catalysts is to regulate the crystal size of heterogeneous porous catalysts like PCP/MOFs due to the huge number of active OMSs. 11 Heck cross–coupling reaction The Heck cross–coupling reaction is the formation of a substituted alkene by the reaction of an unsaturated halide with an alkene in the presence of a base and a catalyst in a solvent [72–74]. It is also known as the Mizoroki–Heck reaction, after Tsutomu Mizoroki and Richard F. Heck; Heck shared the 2010 Nobel prize in chemistry with Ei-ichi Negishi and Akira Suzuki for discovering and developing this carbon–carbon cross coupling reaction. Gotthardt et al. [75] presented a novel method for creating Pd/MOF catalysts, namely the post-synthesis treatment of MIL-53-NH2(Al) deploying PdII acetate and maleic anhydride to immobilize Pd complexes. Through this method, precisely controlled quantities of Pd complexes may be introduced; these complexes are hypothesized to share structural and functional similarities with the highly active homogenous species generated in situ in typical catalytic systems. Because of this, leaching investigations should be adequate to reveal if the reaction pathway is similar to that of conventional supported catalysts or whether contributions from really heterogeneous components are present. Through a two-step post-synthetic modification process of MIL-53-NH2(Al), the catalysts were created. The amine groups of MIL-53-NH2(Al) first reacted with maleic anhydride, creating a side chain that may function as a chelating ligand to aid in the following Pd(II) ions immobilization (Fig. 16 ). In a Heck reaction of aryl halides with styrene, the modulated frameworks Pd@MIL-53-NH2(Al) and MIL-53-NH2(Al)-Mal-Pd as heterogeneous catalysts were deployed due to the high activity of Pd-containing materials in CC coupling reactions (Fig. 17 ). It was determined that the MIL-53-NH2(Al)-Mal-Pd catalyst with immobilized Pd(II) complexes offered the best option for optimizing the reaction's parameters. In addition, a homogeneous (PdII acetate) and a standard heterogeneous (Pd@Al2O3) catalyst were used to evaluate the new catalytic components. In the first experiment, bromobenzene was reacted with styrene to test MIL-53-NH2(Al)-Mal-Pd's catalytic performance. After 3 h, 90% selectivity and practically complete conversion were obtained under optimal conditions. The modified catalyst was then put to the test in a coupling reaction involving styrene and chlorobenzene. As shown by the findings, calcium hydroxide is a more effective base than sodium acetate. Since the activation of the CCl bond requires more energy than that of the CBr, a higher temperature of 160 °C and a longer reaction time (6 h) were required for chlorobenzene. The addition of tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBAB) as a promotional agent increased the stilbene yield even further. The MIL-53-NH2(Al)-Mal-Pd framework achieved a yield of 17% and a conversion of 21% with respect to trans-stilbene. Using the conventional Pd@Al2O3 catalyst, the conversion was barely 11% under the same conditions. The conversion of the uniformly dissolved Pd salt was only marginally greater at 33%. The findings suggest that immobilized Pd complexes expedited the reaction process via a fully heterogeneous route in the MIL-53-NH2(Al)-Mal-Pd system, whereas only homogeneously dissolved species are active in standard supported catalysts. Furthermore, the novel catalyst material has been uncovered to have much reduced leaching than conventional ones. 12 Hydrogenation of alkynes Hydrogenation plays a key role in organic synthesis [76,77]. To improve the catalytic activity of a metal NPs-supported MOF, Peng et al. [78] proposed the deployment of ionic liquid (IL) microphase. Highly scattered tiny metal NPs are predicted to be immobilized on the MOF because the IL microphase provides a suitable environment for stabilizing them. This method offers a new heterogeneous catalyst, Pd/IL/MOF, which claims benefits from all three constituents (the porous MOF, the tiny Pd NPs, and the microphase IL). Under mild conditions, the as-synthesized Pd/IL/MOF catalysts have demonstrated high activity in catalyzing the selective hydrogenation of acetylene hydrocarbons. Pd/IL/MOF was evaluated for its catalytic performance in the selective hydrogenation of various alkynes. In order to produce highly active terminal alkenes, electron-withdrawing and electron-donating phenylacetylenes were selectively hydrogenated (Table 4 , entries 1–4). Pd/IL/MOF catalyst displayed good selectivity and strong activity for the hydrogenation of aliphatic alkynes, and 4-octyne (Table 4, entry 5) and 1-octyne (Table 4, entry 6) as they were converted in 45 and 50 min, respectively, with selectivity higher than 96%. Similarly, the steric effect may explain why the hydrogenation reaction rates of diphenylacetylene (Table 4, entry 7) and 1-phenyl-1-butyne (Table 4, entry 8) are slower than those of the aforementioned. Fig. 18 depicts the architecture of the as-produced Pd/IL/MOF catalyst and its catalytic reaction for the selective hydrogenation of phenylacetylene. Because of the interaction between the MOF's unsaturated Cu2+ sites and the IL's N, the IL was able to attach to the MOF's surface. At the same time, the Pd NPs engage with the IL that has been immobilized on the MOF substrate. Therefore, Pd NPs readily scattered on the MOF as the IL microphase provides an ideal environment for inhibiting the growth or aggregation of Pd NPs. The remarkable catalytic performance of Pd/IL/MOF for phenylacetylene hydrogenation may be traced back to both, the porous MOF structure and the tiny Pd NPs stabilized by IL. Pd NPs, on the one hand, benefit from their small size by enhancing the density of catalytic active sites, which speeds up the reaction effectively. On the other hand, the MOF's porous structure can accelerate the reaction rate by facilitating the diffusion of products and substrates in view of its vast surface area. 13 Hydrogenation of nitroaromatics Hydrogenation of nitroaromatics is a highly desirable catalytic reaction due to the significance of substituted anilines in the chemical industry as they are required for the production of a variety of fine chemical products; pharmaceuticals, polymers, agrochemicals, pigments, cosmetics, and pesticides being the leading examples of such products [79]. MOFs function as support materials for nanocatalysts, stabilizing them and rendering them recyclable. Zhang et al. [80] studied the nitroaromatic reduction to amino compounds catalyzed by Prussian blue analogs (PBAs)@Pd catalyst. Nitrobenzene was reduced to aminobenzene in a model reaction, and the PBAs' catalytic performance was measured while deploying NaBH4. The maximum yield of aminobenzene (33%) could be obtained with the bare PBA material, indicating its promise as a catalyst in this process. As a means of boosting the catalytic activity, Pd NPs were included into PBAs to establish electron transport channels in the PBA support. Fig. 19 is a diagrammatic depiction of the Pd loading procedure wherein the synthesis occurs in water; therefore, the process is environmentally benign, and the reaction is simple to scale up. After the completion of the reaction, powerful ultra-sonication is used to provide a homogeneous distribution and to refine the particle sizes. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images clearly display the decorated Pd NPs, which have a size of ∼5 nm (Fig. 20 a and b). Figs. 20c and d show that Pd NPs are evenly distributed among the PBA framework. In aqueous NaBH4, the catalytic performance of PBA@Pd was demonstrated by reducing nitrobenzene to aminobenzene; loaded Pd NPs are likely responsible for the impressively high yield of 98% (Table 5 ) when a transparent solution ensues after hydrogenation, indicating the successful reaction completion. In addition, nitroaromatic compounds bearing a wide variety of functional groups, such as ‒OH, ‒CH3, ‒Cl, ‒Br, ‒NH3, and ‒NH2 (Table 5), reveal the versatility of this catalytic system for the reduction of nitrobenzenes. PBA@Pd exhibited good performance for a variety of catalytic reduction applications, in all cases, specifically the nitro functional group's reduction to the amino functionality (Table 5). In addition, the recyclability of the PBA@Pd composite nanocatalyst was examined wherein the catalytic activity was maintained as evidenced by the observation of an 82% yield to the target product after 5 successive reduction cycles. These results shed light on the design aspects of electron transmission tunnels and fabrication of the framework materials that exploit PBAs as supports. PBAs are attractive and versatile nanostructured materials due to their remarkable properties, such as high surface area, well-defined framework, and desirable physicochemical attributes, besides their amenability to modification by different functional groups through the stabilization of different sized metal NPs. In this study, combining Pd NPs into PBA allowed the development of facile electron transfer pathways, greatly enhancing the catalyst's performance when deployed for the reduction of nitroaromatics. 14 Isomerization of methylcyclopentane To create Pt NPs embedded in UiO-66 (PtnUiO-66), Choi et al. [81] selected organic linkers with two functional groups, ammonium (‒NH3 +, N) and sulfonic acid (‒SO3H, S), as weak and strong acidic functionalities, respectively, and then incorporated them into UiO-66. Fig. 21 depicts the catalyst's overall design and the functionalized MOFs employed in this investigation; MOF embedded into a single nanocrystal, MOF with Pt NPs on its surface, and MOF without catalyst are all seen in Fig. 21a. As shown in Fig. 21b, the first structure is the one studied, and its chemical functions were altered while the second and third structures served as reference catalysts. The acidic sites in the Pt⊂nUiO-66-S and N functional groups were neutralized so that the impact of acidity could be investigated further. Pt⊂nUiO-66-S* exhibited catalytic behavior (Fig. 22 a) that was indistinguishable from that of the reference catalyst Pt⊂nUiO-66, which lacked functional groups. Furthermore, compared to the reference catalyst, their catalytic activity was drastically lower (Fig. 22b). Subsequently, two acidic functional groups of varying intensities were combined and placed into Pt⊂nUiO-66 to create Pt⊂nUiO-66-SN. As can be seen in Fig. 22a, the Pt⊂nUiO-66-SN caused a drastic shift in the product selectivity. In this case, cyclohexane was not formed while benzene (51.7%), acyclic isomers (26.7%), and olefin (21.6%), were the primary products instead. Notably, cyclohexane is the dominant product with no acyclic isomers when the Pt⊂nUiO-66-S with only ‒SO3H functional group is used. Unexpectedly, the presence of two acidic functional groups of differing strengths appears to alter the catalytic pathway while maintaining the high activity of the strong acidic functional group (Pt⊂nUiO-66-S); two-fold greater activity in comparison with Pt⊂nUiO-66-N and the reference catalyst (Fig. 22b) is discerned. For the purpose of creating Pt⊂nUiO-66-S*N and S*N*, respectively, the authors deprotonated two acidic functional groups either separately or concurrently in this mixed catalyst. As a result, Pt⊂nUiO-66-S*N behaved like Pt⊂nUiO-66-N, while Pt⊂nUiO-66-S*N* performed similarly to the reference catalyst (Pt⊂nUiO-66) with no functional groups (Figs. 22a and b). These findings suggest that functional group protonation is essential for the catalytic activity. The design comprising the incorporation of Pt NPs into MOFs was demonstrated to be ideal for modifying the chemical environment of the system due to the capacity to functionalize the MOF catalyst. The study's main discovery is that the basic, acidic, and neutral features offered by MOFs bearing Pt NPs had the ability to alter the catalytic pathway for methylcyclopentane transformation, activity, and selectivity. 15 Multicomponent reactions The use of multicomponent reactions for the preparation of natural, organic, and pharmaceutical products has grown in demand over the last decade [82]. They are typically described as one-pot processes wherein two or more starting materials combine to produce an intended single product. To accomplish organic multicomponent transformations, Koolivand et al. [83] created citric acid (CA) and coordinative polymers (CP) bearing nickel as a novel catalyst (Ni-CP) as depicted in Fig. 23 for a visual representation of its topological architecture. The ensued catalyst was characterized by BET, XRD, SEM, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), wavelength-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy, energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS), and atomic absorption spectroscopy. Ni-CP was investigated as a potential CP catalyst due to its high efficiency, recyclability, stability, and commercial availability in the preparation of 2,3-dihydroquinazolin-4(1H)-one derivatives. At first, the model reaction was used to examine the impact of solvent, and it was found that ethanol solvent afforded the highest yields in shortest reaction times. Both the Ni-CP concentration and the impact of temperature were studied under ideal conditions; Ni-CP must be used as a catalyst for this reaction at 80 °C. In order to determine the full potential of this method, the optimized reaction conditions were applied for the preparation of 2,3-dihydroquinazolin-4(1H)-ones; several functional groups on the aromatic ring of an aldehyde, including NO2, F, Br, Cl, OH, OMe, and Me, were all well tolerated. Thus, this method is useful for synthesizing a wide variety of 2,3-dihydroquinazolin-4(1H)-ones with both electron-withdrawing and electron-donating substituents. One putative process for the production of 2,3-dihydroquinazolin-4(1H)-one derivatives in the attendance of Lewis acid's sites is proposed in Fig. 24 . In the first of multiple steps in this method, aldehyde is activated by a Ni-CP catalyst. Second, Imine I is synthesized by attacking an active aldehyde with the amine group of 2-amino benzamide, followed by dehydration of the reaction product. With the help of an intermolecular reaction, intermediate I is transformed into intermediate II. There is an intramolecular nuclear attack on the carbon of the imine, trailed by the tautomerization of amide. After the protons are transferred, the desired 2,3-dihydroquinazolin-4(1H)-one derivatives are produced. From a sustainability viewpoint, this research demonstrates that the Ni-CP catalyst can be recycled up to five times before suffering a noticeable decline in performance. In view of its many beneficial attributes, such as low cost, high stability, and simple separation, this catalyst merits further research for potential commercial application. 16 One-pot tandem reaction One of the most intriguing but challenging reactions in catalysis research is the development of a practical tandem catalyst that resembles nature's multistep transformation cascades [84]. To introduce site-isolated basic and acidic sites into MIL-101, Lee et al. [85] presented a synthetic approach involving direct solvothermal synthesis under mild reaction conditions with two common organic linkers and a single post-synthetic modification step. This method is straightforward, and facilitates to regulate the relative abundance of basic functions and Brønsted acid on its backbone network. By reducing the NO2 groups to NH2 with SnCl2, Fig. 25 shows how MIL-101‒NH2‒SO3H can be prepared with both the base functions and Brønsted acid. MIL-101‒NH2‒SO3H's catalytic activities were assessed by studying its ability to catalyze a one-pot tandem reaction depicted in Table 6 which shows the complete conversion of 1 to 3 with extremely good selectivity (>99%) (entry 5). The remarkable efficiency of the MIL-101‒NH2‒SO3H reaction proves that introducing base sites and Brønsted acid on the organic linkers without sacrificing coordination-unsaturated sites at the metal centers is an efficient design for isolating the site of antagonistic functions in a system. In order to determine the durability of the catalyst, MIL-101‒NH2‒SO3H, several reaction cycles were carried out. After completion of each reaction, the catalyst was filtered out, washed, dried, and put back into service; there was hardly any change in selectivity or conversion subsequent to five successive runs. The XRD pattern and FT-IR spectrum of the recycled catalyst were almost identical from those of the freshly prepared catalyst. 17 Oxidation of alcohols One of the most fundamental chemical transformations deployed in the pharmaceutical and fine-chemical industries is the oxidation of alcohols to aldehydes and ketones [86]. Zhuang et al. [87] disclosed that a TEMPO radical-decorated Zr-MOF, designated UiO-68-TEMPO (Fig. 26 a-c), could be constructed using Zr(IV) as a metal node and covalently incorporating an amino-TEMPO radical into a terphenyl-4,4′-dicarboxylic acid ligand (linker 3). UiO-68-TEMPO crystals with tunable defect structures were produced by adjusting the concentration of the benzoic acid (BA) modulator. The UiO-68-TEMPO single-crystalline with fewer defects was created when the modulator concentration was high; in contrast, severely defective microcrystals were produced with a low concentration of the modulator. It was uncovered that a relatively modest amount of water added to the system significantly increased the catalytic activity of UiO-68-TEMPO. As depicted in Fig. 27 , it is proposed that UiO-68-TEMPO catalyzes the aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol. Tert‑butyl nitrite (TBN) is thermally unstable, and as it decomposes, it releases either NO2 or NO, which function as a redox couple to stimulate the production of molecular oxygen. With the help of NO2, the attached TEMPO radical (5) in MOFs is oxidized to an oxoammonium species (6), which in turn oxidizes the benzyloxide moiety to benzaldehyde on the Zr-node. The catalytic cycle is completed when NO2 oxidizes the reduced hydroxylamine species (TEMPOH, 7), producing the TEMPO cation. According to the suggested mechanism, the high catalytic activity of UiO-68-TEMPO toward alcohol oxidation is due in large part to the synergistic impact between the appended TEMPO radicals and the hydrated Zr-nodes. Since UiO-68-TEMPOmicro has more Zr-node defects than UiO-68-TEMPO single-crystal, this process also explains why UiO-68-TEMPOmicro has higher catalytic performance. In another interesting research, Kim and coworkers functionalized Zr-MOF with TEMPO and synthesized a Zr-MOF-TEMPO catalyst for the sequential one-pot oxidation of alcohols to carboxylic acids [88]. 18 Oxidation of sulfides Catalyzed oxidation of organic compounds has the potential to demonstrate rational chemical design [89]. Sulfoxides are highly sought for the production of therapeutic molecules, physiologically active compounds, and natural products [90]. Two Zr-based porphyrin MOFs, PCN-226 and PCN-222, were synthesized by Sheng et al. [91]. Each is made up of two Zr-oxo nodes, a ZrO7 zigzag chain and a Zr6(μ-OH)8 cluster, respectively, with carboxyl porphyrin ligands. Using red light at 660 nm, Fig. 28 displays the photocatalytic activity of PCN-226 and PCN-222 in conjunction with HOOC-TEMPO for the selective aerobic oxidation of sulfides. It is possible that the faster charge transfer, lesser recombination of photoexcited charge carriers, and higher abundance of mesopores in pure PCN-222 explain why it outperformed PCN-226 in photocatalytic activity. Interestingly, cooperative photocatalysis may have been established, as the addition of 3 mol% HOOC-TEMPO enhanced the yields of the three sulfoxides over PCN-222 by more than 60%. When compared to PCN-226, the addition of HOOC-TEMPO only marginally aided the photocatalytic oxidation of the three examined sulfides. The ZrO7 zigzag chain of PCN-226 might not be as beneficial for integrating HOOC-TEMPO as the Zr6(μ-OH)8 clusters with eight hydroxyl groups of PCN-222. A plausible pathway for the photocatalytic selective aerobic oxidation of sulfide is also offered for this reaction as depicted in Fig. 29 . Initially, after HOOC-TEMPO is introduced into PCN-222 in the dark, the segregation of holes (h +) and electrons (e‒) takes place in PCN-222 when exposed to red light. Then, h + causes the integrated HOOC-TEMPO to oxidize to HOOC-TEMPO+ and the transfer of e‒ creates the critical reactive oxygen species O2 •−. Simultaneously, the reversible integration of HOOC-TEMPO+ drives sulfide oxidation to the radical cation, and subsequently HOOC-TEMPO is produced. Persulfoxide is generated when O2 •− intercepts the sulfide radical cation. Finally, with the aid of an electron and a proton from the solvent CH3OH, sulfoxide may be easily extracted from persulfoxide. 19 Oxidative dehydrogenative homo-coupling of amines to imines and cross-coupling of amines with alcohols to amides Imines play an important part in the synthesis of chemical and biologically active substances such as amines, pyrrolines, and amides [92]. Furthermore, because of the prevalence of this functional group in natural products, synthetic polymers, and pharmaceutical compounds, amide bond formation is one of the most frequently deployed organic reactions. Anbardan et al. [93] reported TBHP as an oxidant and an improved Cu2(BDC)2(DABCO) catalyst for oxidative cross-coupling of amine with alcohols to amides and oxidative homo-coupling of amines to imines (Fig. 30 ). Amides were synthesized from a variety of benzylic alcohols and benzylic amines by optimizing the reaction conditions (Table 7 ) wherein excellent yields of the amides (3a-k) were obtained from amines and benzylic alcohols bearing various substituents. The amide products were most abundant when propyl amine was used as the substrate. Good yields of imines were obtained via oxidative dehydrogenative homo-coupling of benzyl amines deploying benzyl amines containing an electron-donating group in either the para- or ortho-position (entries 1–7). However, benzyl amines encompassing an electron-withdrawing group in the para position resulted in the creation of a small amount of product. (Table 8 ). Fig. 31 depicts a potential mechanism for these reactions. When exposed to Cu(II), TBHP undergoes an oxidation process that results in the formation of a tert‑butylproxy radical. As a result of hydrogen capture by the tert‑butylproxy radical, benzyl alcohol and benzylamine are converted into the 7a and 5a proxy intermediates. These two intermediaries yield benzaldehyde and imine 6a up on removal of TBHP. Imine 3a is formed when benzyl amine is added to imine 6a, which then has the ammonia removed. Additionally, benzyl amine is added to benzaldehyde to produce aminal 8a, and amide 4a is ultimately synthesized via the oxidative dehydrogenation of aminal 8a deploying TBHP and Cu(II). Confirmation of the latter process was offered by the exclusive production of the corresponding amide upon reaction of benzylamine and benzaldehyde under the similar conditions thus the involvement of an aldehyde in the reaction pathway. It was also affirmed that the Cu-MOF catalyst was stable and recyclable as the catalyst could be recovered via filtration, and washed, dried, and reused subsequently in four successive runs. Overall, the outcome suggests that this inexpensive reaction offers a viable alternative for synthesizing imines and amides under mild conditions. 20 Photooxidation of 1,5-dihydroxynaphthalene Ding et al. [94] showed that chemical exfoliation of intercalated MOF materials may be deployed to produce two-dimensional (2D) MOF nanosheets (NSs) in high yield; Fig. 32 shows a simplified diagram of the entire manufacturing procedure. The intercalated MOFs was constructed by incorporating 4,4′-dipyridyl disulfide (DPDS), a chemically labile dipyridyl ligand, between the layered MOF materials. The MOFs could be exfoliated into ultrathin (1 nm) NSs with ∼57% yield due to the weakening of interlayer contacts between enlarged 2D layers following the scissoring of DPDS via chemical reduction of the disulfide bond by deployment of trimethylphosphine (TMP). The authors observed the exfoliated NSs’ possible use in generating 1O2 for heterogeneous photocatalysis. The 1O2 evolution over visible light irradiation with λ higher than 420 nm was detected using 1,3-diphenylisobenzofuran (DPBF). Fig. 33 a shows that when exfoliated MOF nanosheets are present, the absorbance at 410 nm diminishes, indicating the production of 1O2. The NSs that have been chemically exfoliated outperform other specimens when it comes to 1O2 production (Fig. 33b). Consequently, the photooxidation of 1,5-dihydroxynaphthalene (DHN) to produce the corresponding juglone, the oxidized product, is enhanced by the chemically exfoliated 2D MOF NSs (Figs. 33c, d). As a whole, the introduced method shows promising potential for synthesizing diverse ultrathin 2D metal-organic NSs with desired properties and topologies, especially when considering the abundance of metal nodes and organic ligands in MOFs. 21 Si-H insertion reaction By integrating Ir(III)-porphyrin (P) active sites on the pore surface, Wang et al. [95] designed an Ir-P MOF catalyst, [(Hf6(μ3 O)8-(OH)2(H2O)10)2(Ir(TCPP)Cl)3].solvents (Ir-PMOF-1(Hf)), to create catalytic coordination spaces (TCPP stands for tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl)porphyrin)). Ir-PMOF-1(Hf) acts as a multi-channel crystalline molecular flask with a strong confinement impact and simple transport of product/reactant from/into inner reactive vessels because of its permeable and continual channels crosslinking the catalytic coordination spaces. Successful catalyzed primary Si-H insertion reaction with high reactivity and selectivity demonstrates this catalyst as a chemo-selective alternative for typical homogenous catalysts (Fig. 34 ). By using the model reaction of phenylsilane (PhSiH3) and ethyl-2-diazoacetate (EDA), authors could show the superiority of Ir-PMOF-1(Hf) in the Si-H insertion transformations. After 3 min with a 1:5 molar ratio mixture of EDA and PhSiH3 in dichloromethane (DCM), ethyl-2-(phenylsilyl)acetate (2a), the Si-H insertion product, was obtained in 93%, 86%, and 83% yields, respectively, when the reaction was carried out over 0.8 mol [M]% of Ir-PMOF-1(Hf), Ir(TPP)(CO)Cl, and Rh2(OAc)4 (Table 9 , entries 1–3) (TPP stands for 5,10,15,20-tetraphenylporphyrin). Each reaction resulted in the total consumption of EDA. The self-coupling reaction products of EDA, such as maleate and diethyl fumarate, were responsible for the primary EDA in addition to the Si-H insertion products. After 48 h, the yield of 2a produced by the same process catalyzed by Cu(OTf)2 was only 41% (entry 4). A 76% yield was maintained over Ir-PMOF-1(Hf) even when the molar percent of Ir was lowered to 0.04%, but at the expense of a significantly prolonged reaction time of 12 h (entry 5). The turnover number (TON) and TOF of Ir-PMOF-1(Hf) were calculated to be 1900 and 2325 h−1, respectively, based on these catalytic reactions. The outcomes from this study highlight the adaptability of MOF catalysis, which can not only incorporate the best characteristics of homogeneous catalysts but also offer metal catalysts with a special property under heterogeneous conditions, to accomplish catalytic processes that are not possible with homogeneous catalysts. 22 Sonogashira cross-coupling reaction By combining a terminal alkyne and a vinyl or aryl halide in the presence of a catalyst and a base, the Sonogashira reaction forms a carbon-carbon bond [96]. Kiani et al. [97] introduced a new Pd-MOF system, Pd@TMU-16-NH2, that is both highly effective and novel. The Sonogashira cross-coupling reaction between terminal alkynes and aryl halides was catalyzed by deploying this Pd NP catalyst supported on TMU-16-NH2 MOF, which was synthesized via post-synthesis modification. Under optimal reaction conditions, a wide variety of aryl halides including both electron-donating and electron-withdrawing functional groups could be reacted with phenyl acetylene to demonstrate the catalyst's exceptional performance (Fig. 35 ). It was found that aryl iodides with electron-withdrawing functional groups were the most active in the coupling reaction. However, reduced yields were observed when electron-rich iodobenzene was used as substrate. Fig. 36 presents the plausible pathway for more complicated reductive elimination or oxidative addition reactions over supported Pd catalysts. Pd@TMU-16-NH2 first oxidizes the CH bond in phenylacetylene. Acetylide potassium is then formed by removing the hydrogen from acetylene with the base K2CO3. The catalyst also induces the formation of an aryl palladium halide (ArPdX) complex from the aryl halides. In the last step, the acetylide-Pd intermediate reacts with aryl palladium halide to yield the required coupling product, regenerating of the Pd@TMU-16-NH2 nanocatalyst. The catalytic activity of this catalyst decreased from 97% in the first cycle to 80% in the fifth cycle, suggesting the loss of catalyst or leaching during the reuse process (Fig. 37 ). The reused catalyst's XRD pattern revealed that its structure remained stable after five recycles. However, the Pd content in the catalyst was 6.84 wt% before the reaction and 6.54 wt% after the fifth recycling, according to the inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy study. The lower catalytic activity and reusability aspects need to be addressed. Indeed, achieving ideal catalysts with superior activities and durability remains elusive. To accomplish the development of practical catalysts, it is essential to design highly stable MOFs-based catalysts or incorporate MOFs and metal nanocatalysts with regulated properties. 23 Suzuki-Miyaura cross‒coupling reaction Using a Pd catalyst and a base, the Suzuki cross-coupling reaction is an organic process that combines an organohalide and an organoborane to produce the coupled product [98]. For Pd immobilization, Augustyniak and coworkers [99] opted for [Ni(H2BDP‒SO3)2], a pyrazolato-based MOF with sulfonate functions. Since both Pd forms (NPs and ions) are involved in the Suzuki-Miyaura catalytic cycle, the researchers reasoned that the system assembled from 2,5-di(1H-pyrazol-4-yl)benzenesulfonate linkers and Ni(II) cations might be a good MOF support for Pd NPs and Pd2+ (Fig. 38 ). To create Pd[Ni(H2BDP‒SO3)2] catalyst, Pd precursor was incorporated into the MOF by impregnating the system with a methanolic solution of [PdCI2(CH3CN)2] at room temperature. For the purpose of evaluating the catalytic performance of Pd[Ni(H2BDP‒SO3)2] catalyst, and as a model reaction, the C‒C coupling reactions between phenylboronic acid and aryl bromides were chosen. To achieve this objective, 4-bromoanisole was used as a screening substrate to optimize the reaction conditions. In either the presence of pure [Ni(H2BDP‒SO3)2] or the lack of the catalyst, the reaction failed to continue, confirming the catalytic activity of Pd[Ni(H2BDP‒SO3)2] catalyst. In a mixture of 1:1 water and 2-propanol as a solvent, Pd[Ni(H2BDP‒SO3)2] generated up to 91% of the coupling product. Phenylboronic acid reacted with different aryl halides at the same reaction conditions, with conversions ranging from 91% for 4-bromotoluene (Fig. 39 a). Maximum conversions of 97–99% were attained after 4 h of reaction at 60 °C with the products of 4-bromoanisole, 4-bromotoluene, and 2-bromotoluene. Interestingly, Pd[Ni(H2BDP-SO3)2] catalyst could present carbonylative Suzuki cross–coupling of aryl iodides with arylboronic acid (Fig. 39b). In terms of its reusability, the catalyst may be cleaned and reused for at least four cycles before suffering a noticeable decline in performance (Fig. 39c). Due to the encouraging findings, these composites warrant additional study to determine its commercial viability. The application of MOF nanostructured catalysts has opened up a new research area in organic transformations, including the reuse of the designed catalyst [100–102]. Yet, several problems that hinder the commercialization of these catalysts arise, including low reactivity and selectivity, the need for rigorous reaction conditions, and catalyst leaching. Many obstacles need to be resolved before practical applications can be realized, among them the decline of activity and stability, and also the accomplishment of regio- and chemo-selectivity in asymmetrical transformations being the prominent ones. For efficient applications, the utilization of highly stable and durable MOF catalysts, structural preservation, mild and greener reaction conditions, cost effectiveness, and the engineering of simple preparation methods have to be optimized [103–112]. 24 Conclusions, outlooks, and perspectives In order to build environmentally friendly, cost-effective, and longer-lasting catalytic processes, scientists have made significant strides in recent decades in the modification and application of various materials, in the manufacture of heterogeneous catalysts. As such, the development of unique and adaptable architectures like MOF hybrids is an exciting field of study. The integration of NPs with the remarkable capabilities of MOFs encourages the successful fabrication of newer synthetic composites with improved features compared to the one-component counterparts. Recent advances in employing MOFs for organic transformations, encompassing the amidation of aldehydes and amines, arylation of unactivated arenes, Baeyer-Villiger oxidation, cyanation of aldehydes, cycloalkane oxidation, deacetalization-Knoevenagel condensation reactions, desulfurization of thiophene-type sulfur compounds, epoxidation of cyclohexene, esterification reactions, Heck reaction, hydrogenation of alkynes, hydrogenation of nitroaromatics, isomerization reactions of methylcyclopentane, multicomponent reactions, tandem reactions, oxidation of alcohols and sulfides, oxidative dehydrogenative homo-coupling of amines to imines, cross-coupling of amines with alcohols to amides, photooxidation of 1,5-dihydroxynaphthalene, Si-H insertion reaction, Sonogashira and Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reaction, are outlined in this review. Some problems, pertaining to their longevity and the resulting low reactivity and selectivity of catalysts, are highlighted by several studies, which ought to be addressed. Furthermore, the true acid strength, catalytic sites, and their density are especially challenging to determine since Brønsted and Lewis sites typically coexist in MOFs. Additionally, because of several difficulties encountered during their preparation, MOFs have not been widely used in the chemical industry. Catalyst leaching and activity degradation are other significant obstacles that need to be circumvented. The collected data in this review confirms, in general, that current catalytic deployments of MOFs for organic reactions allow the establishment of a solid groundwork for further research and development. Research in the coming years could fully explore and harness the true potential of reticular chemistry, which could help answer the issues that modern chemistry has in the fields of energy conversion, designing environmentally friendly processes, and producing high added value products. coredata.dc:description: In the heterogeneous catalyst domain, there has been an incessant demand in recent decades with a focus on introducing environmentally friendly and sustainable materials. Because of their distinct structural properties, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are emerging as a new class of active materials for organic reactions; sophisticated hybrid catalytic materials can now be fabricated with improved recyclability, separability, and activity for specific organic processes by integrating MOFs with metallic nanoparticles. Herein, we deliberate on several MOF-based nanostructured catalysts that facilitate selected organic transformations. Examples comprise, among others, the Baeyer-Villiger oxidation, cyanation of aldehydes, cycloalkane oxidation, epoxidation of cyclohexenes, esterification, Heck reaction, tandem reactions, Sonogashira and Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reactions, which exploit the catalysts' reactivity, reusability, and interactions with the inherent properties of the deployed MOF-based nanostructured catalysts. The benefits, shortcomings, reusability, and efficiency aspects of the introduced catalysts are reviewed. A succinct conclusion is offered, along with a commentary on the major hurdles encountered today and prospective future research needs related to the MOF-based catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Metal-organic framework-based nanostructured catalysts: Applications in efficient organic transformations
